questions.question: A small amount of a powder can dissolve in water to form a clear solution. When this solution is mixed with K<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>(aq), a white precipitate is obtained. What can the powder be?
Which of the following statements concerning CH<sub>3</sub>COOH and HCl is correct?

options.content: CH<sub>3</sub>COOH is a stronger acid than HCl
The pH of 0.1 M CH<sub>3</sub>COOH(aq) is lower than that of 0.1 M HCl(aq)
Both CH<sub>3</sub>COOH(aq) and HCl(aq) react with NH<sub>3</sub>(aq), each giving a salt
Both CH<sub>3</sub>COOH(aq) and HCl(aq) react with Ag(s), each giving a colourless gas

questions.question:
A sample of 1.02 g of potassium hydrogenphthalate (C<sub>8</sub>H<sub>5</sub>O<sub>4</sub>K) is dissolved completely in distilled water, and then diluted to 250.0 cm<sup>3</sup>. What is the concentration of the solution obtained?
(Relative atomic masses: H = 1.0, C = 12.0, O = 16.0, K = 39.1)
Which of the following pairs of reactants would react in water to give out the largest amount of heat?

options.content: 1 mol of HCl and 1 mol of KOH
1 mol of H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> and 2 mol of KOH
1 mol of (COOH)<sub>2</sub> and 2 mol of KOH
1 mol of CH<sub>3</sub>COOH and 1 mol of KOH

questions.question:
In which of the following processes would a colourless gas evolve?
(1) Magnesium is added to dilute sulphuric acid
(2) Ammonium chloride is heated with calcium hydroxide
(3) Water is added to a solid mixture of citric acid and sodium hydrogencarbonate

A gel containing NaCl(aq), K<sub>3</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>(aq) and phenolphthalein is yellow in colour. An iron nail is put into the gel and corrodes after a period of time. Which of the following colours would NOT be observed in the gel after the iron nail corrodes?

Which of the following methods can be used to distinguish between ZnCl2(aq) and CaBr(aq)?
(1) adding NH3(aq)
(2) performing flame test
(3) evaporating to dryness

Solid Y is soluble in cold water. When an aqueous solution of Y is added separately to sodium hydroxide solution and to acidified silver nitrate solution, a white precipitate is formed in both cases. Which of the following compounds might Y be?
Which of the following reaction routes can best be used to prepare barium sulphate from barium carbonate?
Which of the following statements about potassium hydroxide solution is INCORRECT?

options.content: When potassium hydroxide solution is added to iron(III) sulphate solution, a dirty green precipitate is formed
When potassium hydroxide solution is heated with ammonium chloride solution, ammonia gas is liberated
Dilute potassium hydroxide solution contains K<sup>+</sup>(aq) ions, H<sup>+</sup>(aq) ions and OH<sup>-</sup>(aq) ions
Concentrated potassium hydroxide solution is corrosive

questions.question:
Consider the four solutions W, X, Y and Z listed below:
W: 0.01 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> HNO<sub>3</sub>(aq)
X: 0.01 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>(aq)
Y: 0.01 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> KOH(aq)
Z: 0.10 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> KOH(aq)
Which of the following represents the four solutions arranged in increasing order of pH?
Which of the following pairs of aqueous solutions, when mixed, would give a precipitate?

options.content: iron(II) sulphate and acidified potassium dichromate

questions.question:
50.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.6 M FeSO<sub>4</sub>(aq) is mixed with 150.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.2 M Fe<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(aq). What is the concentration of
SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2-</sup> (aq) ions in the resulting mixture?
Which of the following pairs of aqueous solutions, upon mixing, would have the lowest electrical conductivity?

options.content: 20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M HNO<sub>3</sub> 		and 	20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M KOH
20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> 		and 	20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M Ba(OH)<sub>2</sub>
20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M CH<sub>3</sub>COOH 	and 	20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M NH<sub>3</sub>
20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M HCl 		and 	20.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.1 M C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> (glucose)

questions.question: Which of the following gases, after dissolved in 1 dm<sup>3</sup> of water, would give a solution with the highest pH?

Which of the following processes would show a blue colour?
(1) adding litmus to NaOH(aq)
(2) mixing CuSO<sub>4</sub>(s) and NH<sub>3</sub>(aq)
(3) K<sub>3</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>(aq) and FeCl<sub>2</sub>(aq)
Which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: All aqueous solutions contain H<sup>+</sup>(aq) ions
The pH of all acid solutions is greater than zero
All acidic compounds contain hydrogen as their constituent elements
A ‘corrosive’ hazard warning label must be displayed on all reagent bottles containing acid solution

questions.question: Which of the following salts CANNOT be prepared from the reaction of a metal with a dilute acid?

In an experiment, 25.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of HCl(aq) is measured with apparatus X and is placed in apparatus Y. The HCl(aq) in Y is then titrated with a standard NaOH(aq). Which of the following combinations is correct?
<u>X</u>			         <u>Y</u>

In an experiment to prepare calcium sulphate, excess dilute sulphuric acid is added to 10.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 1.0 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> calcium nitrate solution. Which of the following is the theoretical mass of the calcium sulphate obtained?
(Relative atomic masses: O = 16.0, S = 32.1, Ca = 40.1)
The pH of a sample of sulphuric acid is 2.6. 100 cm<sup>3</sup> of this sample is mixed with 100 cm<sup>3</sup> of water. What is the pH of the resulting mixture?

Consider the following experimental set-up:

![](images/Topic4/dse2016-7-1766394963532-inline-q-qimg-1766394958520-9621-mjgy7ll3-5745.png)

A colourless gas is given out when water is dropped to the mixture. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: Oxalic acid ionises in water to give hydrogen ions
Zinc ionises in water to give zinc ions
Water reacts with oxalic acid to give the colourless gas
Water reacts with zinc to give the colourless gas

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of substances, when mixed together, can be used to prepare copper(II) sulphate crystals?

Which of the following statements concerning vinegar is/are correct?
(1) The process of forming hydrogen ions in vinegar is reversible
(2) Neutralisation occurs when sugar is added to vinegar
(3) The pH of vinegar used in kitchen is around 1

The hazard warning label below is displayed on a bottle containing chemical Z:

![](images/Topic4/dse2016-19-1766395380893-inline-q-qimg-1766395374765-5967-mjgy7mqt-1877.png)

Which of the following chemicals may Z be:
(1) sodium
(2) trichloromethane
(3) concentrated aqueous ammonia
Which of the following statements concerning hydrochloric acid is INCORRECT?

options.content: It does not contain aqueous hydroxide ions

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT the appropriate substance for preparing magnesium sulphate by directly mixing it with dilute sulphuric acid?

Calcium phosphate is insoluble in water. What is the theoretical number of moles of calcium phosphate obtained when 100.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.30 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> CaCl<sub>2</sub>(aq) is mixed with 300.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.10 mol dm<sup>-3</sup> Na<sub>3</sub>P0<sub>4</sub>(aq)?
(Relative atomic masses: O = 16.0, Na = 23.0, P = 31.0, Cl = 35.5, Ca = 40.1)
Which of the following statements concerning zinc is correct?

options.content: It forms a soluble oxide when placed in NH<sub>3</sub>(aq)
It acts as reducing agent when placed in HCl(aq)
It undergoes oxidation when placed in MgCl<sub>2</sub>(aq)
It forms an acidic solution when placed in hot H<sub>2</sub>O(l)

questions.question:
Which of the following statements concerning NaOH(aq) and NH<sub>3</sub>(aq) is/are correct?
(1) Both of them can with MgCl<sub>2</sub>(aq)
(2) Both of them can form a deep blue solution with Cu(OH)<sub>2</sub>(s)
(3) NaOH(aq) can react with CH<sub>3</sub>COOH(aq), but NH<sub>3</sub>(aq) cannot

Which of the following can distinguish a sample of AgNO<sub>3</sub>(aq) from a sample of NaNO<sub>3</sub>(aq)?
(1) adding Cu(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(aq) to the samples
(2) adding HCl(aq) to the samples
(3) adding KOH(aq) to the samples

Dilute sodium hydroxide solution is added to a 0.1 M solution until in excess. Which of the following combinations is correct?
<u>Solution</u>		<u>Observation</u>

options.content: iron(III) sulphate	dirty green precipitate formed

questions.question: Which of the following reagents does NOT react with copper?

Consider the solutions W, X, Y and Z below:
W   |   100 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.20 M HNO<sub>3</sub>(aq)
X    |   50 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.20 M HCl(aq)
Y    |   100 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.20 M CH<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>H(aq)
Z    |   50 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.10 M NaOH(aq)
Which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: Mixing W and Z gives a neutral solution
The pH of the mixture of W and X is lower than that of W
The pH of the mixture of W and X is lower than that of the mixture of X and Y

questions.question: 1st statement To completely neutralise 1 mole of HCl(aq), the number of moles of NH3(aq) needed is more than the number of moles of KOH(aq) needed 2nd statement NH3(aq) is a weaker alkali than KOH(aq)

options.content: Both statements are true and the 2nd statement is a correct explanation of the 1st statement
Both statements are true but the 2nd statement is NOT a correct explanation of the 1st statement
The 1st statement is false but the 2nd statement is true

questions.question: 25.00 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.051 M C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>(aq) can completely neutralise 22.18 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.115 M KOH(aq). What is the basicity of the acid C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>?

25.00 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.50 M lead(II) nitrate solution is mixed with 50.00 cm<sup>3</sup> of 1.00 M sodium chloride solution. Insoluble lead(II) chloride is formed during mixing. What is the concentration of Cl<sup>-</sup>(aq) in the mixture?

topics: Topic 7: Redox Reactions, Chemical Cells and Electrolysis
questions.question:
Which of the following chemicals can be used to distinguish concentrated hydrochloric acid from concentrated nitric acid?
(1) sodium carbonate solid
(2) silver nitrate solution
(3) copper metal

Aqueous calcium hydroxide can be used to
(1) neutralise acidic substances in soil
(2) distinguish carbon dioxide from carbon monoxide
(3) remove sulphur dioxide from a polluted air sample

Which of the following combinations would give a brown gas when putting X in Y?
<u>X</u>			        <u>Y</u>

A reaction occurs when water is dropped into the mixture in the set-up below. A colourless gas is given out

![](images/Topic4/dse2020-11-1766470888898-inline-q-qimg-1766470880927-787-mji7j0c8-8283.png)

What is the role of water in this reaction?

options.content: Water reacts with sodium carbonate to give the colourless gas
Water reacts with citric acid to give the colourless gas
Water is a medium for the formation of carbonate ions from sodium carbonate
Water is a medium for the formation of hydrogen ions from citric acid

questions.question:
Which of the following ways is/are acceptable in the storage of the chemical concerned?
(1) Store concentrated H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>(l) in a copper container
(2) Store concentrated AgNO<sub>3</sub>(aq) in a brown glass container
(3) Store concentrated Pb(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(aq) in an iron container

Which of the following steps can be involved in preparing copper(II) chloride crystals?
(1) Add CuCO<sub>3</sub>(s) to HCl(aq)
(2) Add Cu(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(s) to NaCl(aq)
(3) Add Cu(s) to HCl(aq)

M, Q and R are three different metals. When their oxides are separately heated, only the oxide of M gives a metallic lustre. When their carbonates are separately heated with a Bunsen burner, only the carbonate of R gives no observable changes. Which of the following shows the increasing order of reactivity of the metals?

15.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.20 M Ba(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(aq) is added to 25.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.10 M Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>(aq). After the reaction is completed, which of the following ions has the highest concentration in the mixture?

W, X, Y and Z, each represents one of the following solutions:
HCl (aq)	NaOH(aq)	MgCl<sub>2</sub>(aq)	Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>(aq)
Given that:
Mixing W and X gives a white precipitate
Mixing W and Y gives a white precipitate
Mixing W and Z gives a clear colourless solution
What is Z?

A sample of sulphuric acid was completely neutralised by 25.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.200 M potassium hydroxide solution. The salt solution obtained was then made up to 100.0 cm<sup>3</sup> with deionised water. What is the concentration of the resulting salt solution?
1st statement Iron(II) hydroxide is a base 2nd statement Iron(II) hydroxide is insoluble in water

options.content: Both statements are true and the 2nd statement is a correct explanation of the 1st statement
Both statements are true but the 2nd statement is NOT a correct explanation of the 1st statement
The 1st statement is false but the 2nd statement is true

questions.question: Which of the following is an INCORRECT procedure in titration?

options.content: Rinse the pipette with the solution to be delivered before titration
Rinse the conical flask with the solution to be held before titration
Take the burette readings with eyes on the same level as the meniscus
Make sure that there are no air bubbles in the burette filled with the titrant

questions.question:
A small piece of sodium is added to water containing a few drops of universal indicator. Which of the following statements is/are correct?
(1) Sodium moves quickly on the water surface
(2) The resulting solution shows a red colour
(3) This reaction is exothermic

Both A and B are monobasic acids. The pH of 0.10 M A(aq) is 1.0 and the pH of 0.10 M B(aq) is 3.0. Which of the following statements are correct?
(1) A is a stronger acid than B
(2) Some B molecules are present in B(aq)
(3) Complete neutralisation of 25.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.10 M A(aq) and complete neutralisation of 25.0 cm<sup>3</sup> of 0.10 M B(aq) require the same number of moles of NaOH(aq)
